Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

In my opinion, Colleges should participate in giving back to student athletes. Students who play on their college teams should reap, at least some, of the rewards made off of them. Young people who participate in fairly dangerous sports, often are injured DURING their college years, meaning they are basically "thrown" away. They get nothing for their sacrifice. They made a ton of money for the school, but can't enjoy any benefit, except for the brief time they were playing, getting recognition. 

I have some tangential connection to this. I was able to get a college education due to my Tuba Playing abilities, getting a band scholarship.  This was made sort of possible because of the football teams at my college, and the semi fame of the music program there.  I saw many of the athletes, whom I went to class with, overtired, barely making it. One of my classmates is now sort of Famous. He's Scottie Pippin. I'm telling the complete truth here. He as a tall talented person during College but none of us had any real idea about how famous he'd eventually become.  His family and he struggled these years. It would have been so much better if he could have got a nice endorsement while playing at UCA, my Alma Mater. Even if it would have been fairly modest, it would have meant the world to his family.  They could have enjoyed, at least, knowing they had a roof over their heads, and someplace safe to rest.

This is forbidden, even though athletes give their educational, physical, and emotional selves so fully.
